com.soa.message

Interface Message

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    SOAPMessage
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractMessage, SimpleMessage

    public interface Message
    Represents an XML service message with optional properties and attachments.
    Since:
    5.0

    • Method Summary

    • Method Detail

      • getID

        java.lang.String getID()
        Returns the ID of the message (if any). An ID is typically used when the message is part of an asynchronous exchange. It may not be available for synchronous exchanges. If present, the ID will be unique between the producer and consumer of the messsage while the exchange it is part of is active.
        Returns:
        String identifier of the message, null if none available.

      • setID

        void setID(java.lang.String id)
        Changes the ID of the message. The ID will be unique between the producer and consumer of the messsage while the exchange it is part of is active.
        Parameters:
        id - String identifier of the message.

      • getCorrelationID

        java.lang.String getCorrelationID()
        Returns a correlation identifier (if any) that can be used to correlate this message with another. The most common example is for correlating an asynchronous response to a request message. This would be done by using the request message's ID as the response message's correlation ID.
        Returns:
        String correlation identifier, null if none available.

      • setCorrelationID

        void setCorrelationID(java.lang.String id)
        Changes the correlation ID of the message. The most common use is for asynchronous messaging. The request message ID would be set as the response message's correlation ID.
        Parameters:
        id - String correlation identifier.

      • setSecuritySubject

        void setSecuritySubject(javax.security.auth.Subject subject)
        Changes the security subject for the message with the consumer subject category (urn:org:federatedgovernance:security:subject-category:consumer). The security subject identifies the entity sending the message. This is a convenience method as a Map of all subjects associated with the message can be accessed through the MessageProperties.SECURITY_SUBJECTS property.
        Parameters:
        subject - Subject identifying the application sending the message.

      • getSecuritySubject

        javax.security.auth.Subject getSecuritySubject()
        Returns the security subject for the message with the consumer subject category (urn:org:federatedgovernance:security:subject-category:consumer). The security subject identifies the entity sending the message. This is a convenience method as a Map of all subjects associated with the message can be accessed through the MessageProperties.SECURITY_SUBJECTS property.
        Returns:
        Subject identifying the application sending the message.

      • getContent

        javax.xml.transform.Source getContent()
                               throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Returns the content of the message. WARNING: Do not make changes directly to the returned Source object without calling setContent(Source).
        Returns:
        Source holding the message content.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException - Thrown if unable to retrieve message content. Possibly caused by badly formed content.

      • setContent

        void setContent(javax.xml.transform.Source content)
         throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Changes the message content. If normalized either use this method for setting content or addPart(String,Object) if multiple parts are needed. Do not use both methods.
        Parameters:
        content - Source holding the message content.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException - Thrown if unable to change the content. Possibly caused by passing in badly formed content.

      • addAttachment

        void addAttachment(javax.activation.DataHandler content,
                   Headers headers)
            throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Adds an attachment to the message.
        Parameters:
        content - Content of the attachment.
        headers - Any headers that are transported along with the attachment content.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException

      • setAttachments

        void setAttachments(MessageAttachments attachments)
             throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Replaces the attachments of the message in one call for optimization.
        Parameters:
        attachments - MessageAttachments instance.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException

      • getAttachments

        MessageAttachments getAttachments()
        Provides direct access to the attachments for the message.
        Returns:
        MessageAttachments, will be null if there are no attachments for this message.

      • getProperty

        java.lang.Object getProperty(java.lang.String name)
        Returns the property with the given name.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the property.
        Returns:
        Object value of the property, null if not found.

      • setProperty

        void setProperty(java.lang.String name,
                 java.lang.Object property)
        Associates a property with the message.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the property.
        property - Value of the property.

      • getPropertyNames

        java.util.Set getPropertyNames()
        Returns the names of the properties associated with the message. Changes made to the Set are reflected in the message, so if a name is removed from the Set, the property is removed from the message. Names cannot be added however.
        Returns:
        Set of String property names.

      • setProperties

        void setProperties(java.util.Map properties)
        Replaces the properties of the message in one call for optimization.
        Parameters:
        properties - Map of properties keyed by a String.

      • getProperties

        java.util.Map getProperties()
        Provides direct access to the Map of properties for the message. Do NOT make changes to the returned Map.
        Returns:
        Map of properties keyed by Strings.

      • getTransportHeaders

        Headers getTransportHeaders()
        Returns the transport headers associated with the message (if any). This is a convenience method as the same headers can be accessed through the MessageProperties.TRANSPORT_HEADERS property.
        Returns:
        Headers holding transport headers for the message, null if none present.

      • setTransportHeaders

        void setTransportHeaders(Headers headers)
        Replaces the set of transport headers associated with the message. This is a convenience method as the same headers can be accessed through the MessageProperties.TRANSPORT_HEADERS property.
        Parameters:
        headers - Headers holding transport headers for the message.

      • isFault

        boolean isFault()
         throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Returns whether or not the message is a fault message.
        Returns:
        True if a fault, false if not.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException

      • isNormalized

        boolean isNormalized()
        Returns whether the message is normalized or not.
        Returns:
        True if normalized, false if not.

      • canNormalize

        boolean canNormalize()
        Returns whether the message can be normalized or not. Some types of messages may not support normalization.
        Returns:
        True if can be normalized, false if not.

      • copy

        Message copy()
      throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Create a copy of the message. Message normalization state and content are left intact. The returned message will have a copy of the message internal state, including any message properties.
        Returns:
        A copy of this Message.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException - Thrown if unable to copy.

      • normalize

        Message normalize()
           throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Normalizes the message. All defined message parts are taken from their bound encodings and placed in the message's parts map. A new normalized version of the message is returned. Due to the possibility of this original object using InputStreams to hold its content, after normalization this object's InputStreams will most likely be exhausted making this object unusable. To continue to use this object after normalization in its original bound format, use normalizeCopyToXML() instead.
        Returns:
        Normalized Message.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException - Thrown if unable to normalize.

      • normalizeCopy

        Message normalizeCopy()
               throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Normalizes the message leaving the original bound object unchanged. All defined message parts are taken from their bound encodings and placed in the message's parts map. A new normalized version of the message is returned. In order to leave the original object intact it must be copied which may be expensive from a performance perspective.
        Returns:
        Normalized Message.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException - Thrown if unable to normalize.

      • normalizeToXML

        Message normalizeToXML()
                throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Normalizes the message to an XML format. All defined message parts are taken from their bound encodings and placed in the message's parts map. The part identified as the content part (see getContentPartName()) will be translated into an XML representation. A new normalized version of the message is returned. Due to the possibility of this original object using InputStreams to hold its content, after normalization this object's InputStreams will most likely be exhausted making this object unusable. To continue to use this object after normalization in its original bound format, use normalizeCopyToXML() instead.
        Returns:
        Normalized Message.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException - Thrown if unable to normalize.

      • normalizeCopyToXML

        Message normalizeCopyToXML()
                    throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Normalizes the message to an XML format leaving the original bound object unchanged. All defined message parts are taken from their bound encodings and placed in the message's parts map. The part identified as the content part (see getContentPartName()) will be translated into an XML representation. A new normalized version of the message is returned. In order to leave the original object in tact it must be copied which may be expensive from a performance perspective.
        Returns:
        Normalized Message.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException - Thrown if unable to normalize.

      • canCarryBindingHeaders

        boolean canCarryBindingHeaders()
        Returns if the message can carry binding headers. Some types of messages are sent using protocols that don't support binding headers. Indicating that can save processing time during mediation.
        Returns:
        true if binding headers may be use, false if not.

      • getBindingURI

        java.lang.String getBindingURI()
        Returns the URI of the message's binding if the message is bound (not normalized).
        Returns:
        String URI of the message's binding, null if normalized.

      • getContentType

        java.lang.String getContentType()
        Returns the type of content of the message, i.e., application/xml, application/json.
        Returns:
        Type of message content.

      • setContentType

        void setContentType(java.lang.String contentType)
        Changes the type of content of the message, i.e., application/xml, application/json. This must match what is returned in getContent().
        Parameters:
        contentType - Type of message content.

      • addPart

        void addPart(java.lang.String name,
             java.lang.Object part)
        Normalized messages can support multiple parts. A part is synonymous with a message part as defined in the WSDL 1.1 spec, it is a named piece of content. The parts of a normalized message can then be encoded in a protocol specific way by a binding, i.e., query parameters, path parameteters, headers, or RPC encoded XML elements. If the message is not normalized there will be no parts. Use getContent() to get the content of the message. If the message is normalized there may be content accessed using getContent() instead of parts.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the part, should correspond to a WSDL definend message part.
        part - Value/content of the part. Typically a part should be an XML element that corresponds to what is defined in the WSDL definition. A part could be something other than that but unless the consumer of the message can read the content it will fail.

      • getPart

        java.lang.Object getPart(java.lang.String name)
        Returns the value/content of the part with the given name.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the part.
        Returns:
        Value/content of the part.

      • getContentPartName

        java.lang.String getContentPartName()
        When using parts in a message one of those parts can be considered the content of the message (see getContent()). This method will return the name of the part that holds the content.
        Returns:
        Part name holding the message content.

      • setContentPartName

        void setContentPartName(java.lang.String name)
        When using parts in a message one of those parts can be considered the content of the message (see getContent()). This method can be used to specify the name of the part that should be considered the message content.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the part holding the message content.

      • getPartNames

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getPartNames()
        Returns the names of the parts in the message (if any).
        Returns:
        Set of part names. The set is mutable so changes to the set will be reflected in the message.

      • arePartsEmpty

        boolean arePartsEmpty()
        Returns whether there are any parts or not (empty) in the message. If there are no parts there is likely content returned in getContent().
        Returns:
        true if no parts in message, false if there are.

      • getParts

        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> getParts()
        Returns a map of parts keyed by their name.
        Returns:
        Map of parts keyed by their name. The map is muutable so any changes will be reflected in the message. If there are no parts defined null will be returned.
